title: AI Design Tools: The Future of Event Planning Inspiration?
excerpt: Exploring how new AI image generation technology is changing how I create mood boards and communicate design concepts to clients.
content:
Bougie wedding client asked last month if I've tried "Midjourney" yet. I was like what?? Cue 1am internet rabbit hole (as you do), and now I'm weeks deep into this AI pic generator. Still processing what this means for those of us who actually make stuff for a living.

If you haven't heard of it (I hadn't!), Midjourney = type what you want to see, and boom - AI spits out images. Like ACTUAL images that sometimes look freakishly good. Weird and mind-blowing.

First tries = total trash. Typed "elegant wedding table with NZ elements" and got bizarre mashups like a tourism ad had a baby with wedding mag. But after tweaking prompts (gotta be super specific), some actually looked... decent? Useful even?

Started using these AI pics in client meetings for mood boards. Instead of 3-hour Pinterest hunts for that *perfect* inspo image, I generate something close to what's in my head. Game changer for explaining vibes to clients who don't "get it".

The Good & The WTF

Big win = speed. Mood boards that took days now happen during lunch break. Real magic? Showing clients different versions of "rustic elegance" or whatever buzzwords they're fixated on.

Had this picky client saying they wanted "understated luxury with natural elements" for winter wedding. We were picturing totally different things. Showed them AI versions, they pointed and went "THAT ONE" and we FINALLY got somewhere. Saved weeks of back-and-forth.

But these tools get weird sometimes. Hands with 6 fingers. Melty champagne glasses. Chandeliers defying physics. Good for vibes, useless for actual planning.

Plus AI knows NOTHING about real event problems. Sure it shows gorgeous ceiling installation with 10,000 fresh flowers, but zero clue about weight limits, structural engineering, or those blooms turning to sad brown mush after 5 hours in summer heat.

The Awkward Ethics Bit

Not gonna lie, this stuff makes me uncomfortable. I work with amazing photographers, florists and designers. These AI models trained on their work without asking. Feels... not great.

Super clear with clients these are just inspo starting points. Still hire (and pay!!) real creatives for actual work. Some vendor friends freaking out about this tech, others already using it to brainstorm. Interesting times.

Finding My Way

For now, treating this as another tool - helpful for ideas and client convos, not replacing the talented humans who make events happen.

Coolest part? Trying combos I'd never think of. Asked for Art Deco mixed with MƒÅori design elements for corporate event. Most results = culturally cringey garbage, but couple sparked unexpected ideas. Then did proper research and talked to actual cultural advisors cuz AI is clueless about cultural nuance.

This tech evolving scary fast. July's output looks like kindergarten art compared to August's. And apparently next version already way better?!

End of day, our job isn't just pretty pictures. It's knowing how guests move through spaces, how drunk people behave after midnight, how sunset timing affects everything, and how to EXECUTE, not just imagine. No AI replacing actual expertise (yet???).

Any other event peeps trying this? Loving it, hating it, or conflicted like me?
